questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of difficulty walking for the past 4 hours. She first noticed her symptoms after getting up this morning and she was dragging her right foot while walking. She feels tired. She has a history of chronic sinusitis. Six months ago, she was diagnosed with asthma. Current medications include an albuterol inhaler and inhaled corticosteroids. Her temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 80/min, and her blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg. Auscultation of her lungs shows diffuse wheezing over bilateral lung fields. Physical examination shows tender subcutaneous nodules on the extensor surfaces of the elbows. There are palpable, nonblanching erythematous lesions on both shins. Dorsiflexion of the right foot is impaired. Sensation to pinprick, light touch, and vibration is decreased over the ulnar aspect of the left forearm. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
11.3 g/dL


Leukocyte count
24,500


 Segmented neutrophils
48%


 Eosinophils

29%


 Lymphocytes
19%


 Monocytes
4%


Platelet count
290,000/mm3



Serum



 Urea nitrogen
32 mg/dL


 Creatinine
1.85 mg/dL


Urine



 Blood
2+


 Protein
3+


Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA) can manifest with chronic sinusitis, cough, dyspnea, renal damage (as indicated by this patient's elevated BUN and serum creatinine), and palpable purpura. The nasopharyngeal involvement in GPA includes perforation/ulceration of the nasal septum, often leading to a saddle nose deformity. However, adult-onset asthma and marked eosinophilia are not characteristic of GPA.

B) INCORRECT:

Microscopic polyangiitis can manifest with renal damage and palpable purpura. However, microscopic polyangiitis also manifests with hemoptysis and rarely causes sinusitis. In addition, adult-onset asthma and pronounced eosinophilia are not typical of microscopic polyangiitis.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient presents with a cough, dyspnea, and renal damage (as is evident in this patient's elevated BUN and serum creatinine), which is seen in Goodpasture syndrome. However, the presence of palpable purpura, skin nodules, neuropathy, and marked eosinophilia would not be consistent with this diagnosis. Furthermore, this patient lacks hemoptysis, which is frequently seen in patients with Goodpasture syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP) manifests with palpable purpura and signs of renal disease, which is evident in this patient from her elevated BUN and serum creatinine. However, HSP typically manifests in a tetrad of symptoms that also includes arthralgias/arthritis and abdominal pain and is most commonly seen in children.

E) INCORRECT:

Excessive corticosteroids use can lead to elevated blood pressure, malaise, and nonpalpable purpura. However, these effects are only seen in patients taking systemic steroids; inhaled corticosteroids do usually not have significant systemic effects. Furthermore, while steroids may cause easy bruising, this patient has palpable purpura, which is not typically seen in excessive steroid use. Moreover, excessive steroid use is more likely to cause muscle weakness (myopathy) than polyneuropathy and manifests with neutrophilia and eosinopenia, unlike this patient's pronounced eosinophilia.

F) INCORRECT:

Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) mainly manifests with symptoms affecting the joints (stiffness, pain, deformities, etc.) but can manifest with extraarticular symptoms, such as dyspnea, cough, and fatigue in cases of pulmonary involvement or palpable purpura and neuropathy in cases of vasculitis. Furthermore, RA manifests with palpable subcutaneous nodules on the extensor surfaces of the elbows (rheumatoid nodules). Extraarticular symptoms, such as vasculitis, are typically seen in patients with long-standing, severe RA. This patient lacks articular symptoms, and the presence of pronounced eosinophilia and chronic sinusitis is more suggestive of a different diagnosis.

G) INCORRECT:

Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) manifests with subcutaneous nodules, renal impairment (as is evident in this patient's elevated BUN and serum creatinine), polyneuropathy, and, occasionally, palpable purpura. However, PAN usually spares the lungs and typically manifests with abdominal pain and melena as well as muscle and joint pain.

H) CORRECT:

This patient presents with adult-onset asthma, chronic sinusitis, mononeuritis multiplex (foot drop, loss of sensation in the distribution of the ulnar nerve), subcutaneous skin nodules, and palpable purpura, all of which are consistent with eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Churg-Strauss syndrome; EGPA). Systemic signs of inflammation such as fatigue and fever are also commonly seen in EGPA. Moreover, patients with EGPA typically have pronounced eosinophilia and renal involvement (indicated by elevated BUN and serum creatinine), as seen here. (See “Small-vessel vasculitides” overview table.)

Treatment involves immunosuppression with glucocorticoids and may include cyclophosphamide.
questions.hint: This patient likely has elevated serum antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies against myeloperoxidase.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with asthma comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of progressively worsening shortness of breath and cough. He also has a history of chronic sinusitis and foot drop. Current medications include an albuterol inhaler and inhaled corticosteroid. Physical examination shows diffuse wheezing over both lung fields and tender subcutaneous nodules on both elbows. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 23,000/mm3 with 26% eosinophils and a serum creatinine of 1.7 mg/dL. Urine microscopy shows red blood cell casts. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA) is a small vessel vasculitis that can also manifest with chronic sinusitis, cough, dyspnea, glomerulonephritis, and subcutaneous nodules. Nasopharyngeal involvement may also occur in GPA, including perforation or ulceration of the nasal septum and saddle nose deformity. However, the marked eosinophilia seen in this patient is not characteristic of GPA.

B) CORRECT:

This patient's history and findings of asthma, chronic sinusitis, peripheral neuropathy, and subcutaneous skin nodules are consistent with a diagnosis of eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA; previously Churg-Strauss syndrome). Peripheral eosinophilia and evidence of glomerulonephritis (e.g., elevated creatinine, RBC casts) further support the diagnosis. EGPA is a small vessel vasculitis characterized by vessel necrosis and granuloma formation; renal biopsy typically shows pauci-immune glomerulonephritis (e.g., no immune deposits detected on immunofluorescence).

C) INCORRECT:

Cough, dyspnea, and glomerulonephritis can be seen in Goodpasture syndrome, a type II hypersensitivity reaction characterized by anti-glomerular basement membrane antibodies. However, the skin nodules, foot drop, and marked eosinophilia in this patient are not consistent with this diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP) classically manifests with the triad of palpable purpura, arthralgias, and abdominal pain, usually in a patient with a recent URI. While it can also cause renal disease, it is uncommon in adults and would not explain this patient's eosinophilia, chronic sinusitis, and skin nodules.

E) INCORRECT:

Microscopic polyangiitis is a non-granulomatous small vessel vasculitis that can manifest with glomerulonephritis and subcutaneous nodules, which are seen in this patient. However, microscopic polyangiitis rarely causes sinusitis. In addition, pronounced eosinophilia is not typically seen in microscopic polyangiitis.

F) INCORRECT:

Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) is a type III hypersensitivity reaction that can also manifest with subcutaneous nodules, renal impairment, and peripheral neuropathy. It most commonly affects men and is associated with hepatitis B infection. However, PAN usually spares the lungs, and this patient is lacking other classic symptoms of PAN, such as abdominal pain, melena, and weight loss.
questions.hint: This patient has features of both upper and lower respiratory disease (sinusitis and asthma), peripheral neuropathy (foot drop), peripheral eosinophilia, and glomerulonephritis (RBC casts, elevated creatinine). Further evaluation of this patient would most likely show elevated serum antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies against myeloperoxidase.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman with a history of chronic sinusitis and poorly controlled asthma requiring intermittent use of prednisone reports worsening dyspnea, wheezing, and coughing. Controller and rescue inhalers have not provided relief. She complains that her symptoms became acutely worse after a taper of prednisone, which had been prescribed in addition to montelukast.
On review of systems, she notes scant hemoptysis and occasional epistaxis in the past 4 to 6 weeks. She recently returned from a 10-day business trip to Brazil. On examination, she appears uncomfortable and is coughing, with audible, diffuse expiratory wheezing in both lungs.
She is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative. Laboratory testing reveals a leukocyte count of 11,000 per mm3 (reference range, 4500–11,000) with 11% eosinophils (0–8%) and an absolute eosinophil count of 1210 per mm3 (0–350).
A CT scan of the chest is obtained (figure).
Which one of the following diagnostic tests would be the most useful in evaluating this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Anti-scleroderma-70 antibodies are associated with scleroderma, which is linked with interstitial lung disease and pulmonary hypertension but not commonly associated with refractory asthma symptoms and eosinophilia.

B) CORRECT:

Vasculitis involving the lungs is most often an antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody (ANCA)-associated vasculitis. Varieties include granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly referred to as Wegener), eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA; formerly referred to as Churg-Strauss syndrome), and microscopic polyangiitis. An ANCA-associated vasculitis can involve the upper airways (e.g., sinuses), lower airways, and kidneys. EGPA is often characterized by asthma symptoms that are refractory to standard therapies and can manifest as peripheral eosinophilia. Chest imaging reveals transient bilateral pulmonary opacities; if biopsied, pulmonary lesions show vasculitis with eosinophilic granulomatous inflammation. EGPA is associated with p-ANCA positivity (antimyeloperoxidase antibodies). An ANCA-associated vasculitis is often responsive to glucocorticoid therapy. Of note, there are reports of patients with severe glucocorticoid-dependent asthma presenting with EGPA after the initiation of montelukast (and other leukotriene-modifying agents). Although the exact relationship is unclear, one proposal is that the addition of montelukast is often accompanied by a reduction or discontinuation of glucocorticoids, thereby unmasking EGPA that had been previously treated with the glucocorticoids prescribed for severe asthma.

Key learning point: Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis is a vasculitis associated with antineutrophilic cytoplasmic antibodies and can affect the upper airways, kidneys, and lungs.

C) INCORRECT:

Strongyloides antibody testing would help to diagnose pulmonary strongyloidiasis, which could cause chronic respiratory symptoms, eosinophilia, and infiltrates but is less likely to be associated with chronic epistaxis and sinus symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

Aspergillus antibody testing may help to diagnose conditions such as allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillus, which can manifest as eosinophilia and refractory asthma-like symptoms, but it is not as strongly associated with epistaxis as is an ANCA-associated vasculitis. Chest imaging classically reveals central bronchiectasis with mucus plugging (not seen on this patient’s CT scan).

E) INCORRECT:

Legionella urine antigen is present in patients with Legionella pneumonia, an atypical pneumonia frequently characterized by lobar consolidation.

questions.text:
A 38-year-old woman with a 3-year history of asthma and allergic rhinitis is hospitalized with left-leg weakness and numbness that have made walking difficult. Her asthma, which began 2 years earlier, is currently controlled on inhaled fluticasone and prednisone 10 mg daily. The numbness in her leg started 4 weeks ago in the toes and has progressed to involve her entire foot. The weakness in her leg started the day before hospitalization. She also reports a rash that appeared 2 months ago.
Physical examination confirms a rash on both legs (see figure, which shows the lower right extremity). Neurological examination reveals decreased sensation and weakness of dorsiflexion in the left foot.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
9200
4500–11,000


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
11.0
12.0–16.0


Hematocrit (%)
33.6
36.0–46.0


Platelet count (per mm3)
452,000
150,000–350,000


Neutrophils (%)
50
40–70


Lymphocytes (%)
25
22–44


Eosinophils (%)
20
0–8


Monocytes (%)
5
4–11


Creatinine (mg/dL)
1.0
0.6–1.1


Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA), formerly referred to as Churg-Strauss syndrome, is a small-vessel vasculitis characterized by onset of asthma, allergic rhinitis, and atopy months to years before the vasculitic phase. Marked eosinophilia in the blood and affected tissues is the hallmark of this disorder and distinguishes it most clearly from other forms of small-vessel vasculitis. The vasculitis most often affects the skin (palpable purpura) and the peripheral nervous system (presenting as mononeuritis multiplex or a symmetric peripheral neuropathy, often rapidly progressive). Cardiac involvement leads to the greatest mortality from EGPA. Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody (ANCA) testing is positive in 30% to 40% of patients with EGPA, typically directed against antimyeloperoxidase antibodies (MPO-ANCA) and producing a perinuclear ANCA (p-ANCA) pattern.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a patient presenting with asthma, palpable purpura, peripheral neuropathy, and eosinophilia is eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Peripheral neuropathy due to disseminated Lyme disease does not manifest as vasculitic skin lesions or eosinophilia.

C) INCORRECT:

Hypereosinophilic syndromes can cause eosinophilic pneumonia, myocardial involvement, and circulating eosinophilia, but the presence of preexisting asthma, neuropathy, and positive antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody testing indicate a different diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA; formerly referred to as Wegener’s) can cause purpura and neuropathy, but it is not associated with marked eosinophilia or asthma. In GPA, laboratory work is likely to show positive testing for antibodies to proteinase 3 (PR3-ANCA) with a cytoplasmic-staining pattern on immunofluorescence microscopy of neutrophils (c-ANCA).

E) INCORRECT:

Systemic lupus erythematosus is not associated with asthma or prominent eosinophilia. Although vasculitis causing purpura and acute peripheral neuropathy can occur in systemic lupus erythematosus, this patient lacks the more common clinical and laboratory features of lupus, including leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, and photosensitive rash.

questions.text:
A 43-year-old woman reports a 3-month history of rash and difficulty walking. She has a 2-year history of asthma that has worsened during the past 6 months. She is taking a high-dose inhaled glucocorticoid and a long-acting beta agonist but continues to have coughing at night, chest tightness while walking, and only partial relief with the use of a short-acting beta agonist.
On examination, there is weakness of ankle dorsiflexion bilaterally, severe on the right and mild on the left. She has scattered palpable purpuric skin lesions on both legs.
Her total leukocyte count is 17,000 per mm3 (reference range, 4500–11,000); the leukocyte differential includes 35% eosinophils.
Which one of the following tests is most likely to be diagnostic in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tests for antinuclear antibodies are typically negative in patients with EGPA.

B) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary function testing may reveal obstructive abnormalities, but this test is not specific enough to confirm the diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Electromyography and nerve-conduction studies will confirm the neuropathy but will not specifically confirm that a vasculitis is responsible for the findings.

D) CORRECT:

Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA; formerly referred to as Churg-Strauss syndrome) is a small-vessel vasculitis. The prodromal phase of the disease is characterized by new onset of asthma, which often occurs in adulthood and precedes the presentation of the vasculitis. Eosinophilia is the hallmark of the next phase of the disease. Finally, overt vasculitis develops in the vasculitic phase. Most affected patients develop a vasculitic rash with palpable purpura and petechiae, but erythematous maculopapular lesions or bullae can also occur. The most common neurologic presentation of the vasculitis is mononeuritis multiplex, which results in symptoms such as foot drop or wrist drop. EGPA is best diagnosed by biopsy of an affected organ or tissue; in a patient with evidence of a neuropathy, the best site to biopsy is the sural nerve.

About half of patients with EGPA test positive for antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA). When positive, immunofluorescence most often has a perinuclear pattern (p-ANCA) associated with antimyeloperoxidase (MPO-ANCA) antibodies.

Key learning point: Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis is a small-vessel vasculitis that is best diagnosed by means of biopsy of an affected organ or tissue.

E) INCORRECT:

High-resolution CT of the chest may demonstrate peribronchial thickening or scattered opacities, but this test is not specific enough to confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with recurrent epistaxis. For the past 6 months, she has had intermittent epistaxis episodes that have each resolved spontaneously. Her current nosebleed started this morning and appears to have resolved in the waiting room.
Her medical history includes a recent diagnosis of untreated hypertension as well as increasing lower-extremity edema. Her blood pressure is 155/85 mm Hg. The rest of her vital signs are unremarkable.
On physical examination, anterior rhinoscopy reveals an anterior septal perforation with dried blood at the edges. The visible nasal mucosa appears ulcerated and has extensive crusting.
Urinalysis reveals mild proteinuria. Serum and urine drug test results are negative.
Which one of the following diagnostic approaches is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Tuberculin skin test and culture of the nose for acid-fast bacilli
Treponemal antibody testing and, if positive, rapid plasma reagin testing
Chest radiograph and serum angiotensin-converting-enzyme level
Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody testing and biopsy of an area of ulcerated mucosa
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate testing and biopsy of the temporal artery

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Other systemic diseases can affect the nasal septum — including granulomatous diseases such as tuberculosis, sarcoidosis, leprosy, and tertiary syphilis — but the clinical characteristics in this case are not consistent with those diagnoses.

B) INCORRECT:

Other systemic diseases can affect the nasal septum — including granulomatous diseases such as tuberculosis, sarcoidosis, leprosy, and tertiary syphilis — but the clinical characteristics in this case are not consistent with those diagnoses.

C) INCORRECT:

Other systemic diseases can affect the nasal septum — including granulomatous diseases such as tuberculosis, sarcoidosis, leprosy, and tertiary syphilis — but the clinical characteristics in this case are not consistent with those diagnoses.

D) CORRECT:

The diagnosis of granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly referred to as Wegener's) is suggested by the combination of upper respiratory and kidney findings.

When appropriate, patients with this combination of issues should undergo antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody testing, and the affected mucosa should be biopsied for characteristic noncaseating granulomas. However, antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody results can be negative in patients with this presentation, especially if there is no lung or kidney involvement.

Septal perforation can also be caused by chronic intranasal drug use, especially cocaine. Negative serum and urine drug testing rules out current usage but not prior usage causing the septal perforation. Nasal septal perforations from any cause predispose individuals to recurrent epistaxis because of crusting around the perforation edges; they do not manifest as ulcerations.

Key learning point: The combination of nasal septal perforation, negative drug test results, and clinical evidence of kidney disease should prompt diagnostic evaluation with antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody testing and biopsy of any visible mucosal lesions to diagnose granulomatosis with polyangiitis.

E) INCORRECT:

Erythrocyte sedimentation rate and temporal artery biopsy would be diagnostic for giant-cell arteritis, a disease that does not have nasal involvement.

questions.text:
A 54-year-old man presents with four weeks of persistent nasal congestion and crusting, occasionally streaked with blood. Over the past three days, he has developed hemoptysis. Examination reveals scattered crackles. No peripheral eosinophilia is noted (see lab results).


Test
Result
Normal Values



Urine




 RBC casts
Present
Absent


Creatinine
221 μmol/L
44 - 115 μmol/L



Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Microscopic polyangiitis is an ANCA-associated vasculitis that can cause renal and pulmonary involvement. However, it typically spares the upper airways. The patient's nasal congestion and crusting suggest granulomatous inflammation, which is not characteristic of microscopic polyangiitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis typically presents with asthma, allergic rhinitis, and marked peripheral eosinophilia. The absence of eosinophilia in this patient makes this diagnosis unlikely. Additionally, the chronic nasal symptoms and renal involvement are more characteristic of other ANCA-associated vasculitides.

C) CORRECT:

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis manifests with a triad of upper respiratory tract, lower respiratory tract, and renal involvement. The patient's nasal congestion, crusting, and epistaxis indicate upper airway granulomatous inflammation. Hemoptysis and crackles suggest lower respiratory tract involvement, while red blood cell casts and elevated creatinine reflect rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis. This condition is an antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody-associated vasculitis, primarily mediated by proteinase-3 antibodies.

Key learning point: Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis is characterized by a triad of upper respiratory tract involvement, pulmonary hemorrhage, and rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis.

D) INCORRECT:

Goodpasture syndrome involves anti-glomerular basement membrane antibodies causing pulmonary hemorrhage and glomerulonephritis. However, it does not account for the patient's sinonasal symptoms.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman with a history of asthma presents to the emergency department with fever, malaise, and numbness in her right foot. Vital signs are BP, 110/68; P, 108; R, 20; T, 38.1°C (100.6°F); oxygen saturation, 95% on room air. Examination shows diffuse wheezing and decreased sensation along the lateral aspect of the right foot. Laboratory studies show WBC 18,000/mm³ with 25% eosinophils, creatinine 1.1 mg/dL, and ESR 65 mm/hr. Chest radiograph shows patchy bilateral opacities. What is the most appropriate initial treatment?

choices.text: Broad-spectrum antibiotics and infectious disease consult
Nebulized bronchodilators and outpatient pulmonology follow-up
Intravenous diphenhydramine and famotidine and allergology consult

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although fever and pulmonary infiltrates may suggest pneumonia, the marked eosinophilia, asthma, and neuropathy indicate a vasculitic rather than infectious process. Antibiotics would not address the underlying eosinophilic inflammation driving this patient's presentation.

B) CORRECT:

Correct — The characteristic features of asthma, eosinophilia, and peripheral neuropathy are consistent with eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA). Prompt initiation of systemic corticosteroids is essential to suppress inflammation and prevent irreversible organ damage.

C) INCORRECT:

Immunoglobulins are not part of the standard treatment approach to eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Bronchodilators may relieve wheezing but do not treat the systemic vasculitis causing eosinophilic inflammation and neuropathy. Discharging this patient with symptomatic therapy alone would permit disease progression and potential irreversible nerve and organ injury.

E) INCORRECT:

While the marked eosinophilia might suggest an allergic process, antihistamines alone are insufficient for systemic vasculitis. This patient likely has eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis, which requires a different approach.
